_link.title: I can describe how atomic radius changes across a period and down a group

toLevel2.question: What happens to atomic radius as you go across a period from left to right?

options.text: It decreases
It increases
options.explanation: Atomic radius decreases across a period because increasing nuclear charge pulls electrons closer.

options.text: It stays the same
options.explanation: Atomic radius changes across a period; it decreases due to increasing nuclear charge.

options.text: It first increases then decreases
options.explanation: The general trend is a consistent decrease across a period.

toLevel2.question: What happens to atomic radius as you go down a group?

options.text: It increases
It decreases
options.explanation: Atomic radius increases down a group because additional electron shells are added.

options.text: It stays the same
options.explanation: Atomic radius changes down a group; it increases as more shells are added.

options.text: It first decreases then increases
options.explanation: The trend is a consistent increase down a group.

toLevel2.question: Which element has the largest atomic radius: lithium, sodium, or potassium?

options.text: Potassium
Lithium
options.explanation: Lithium is at the top of Group 1 and has the smallest radius; radius increases going down.

options.text: Sodium
options.explanation: Sodium is between lithium and potassium; potassium has the most shells and largest radius.

options.text: They all have the same radius
options.explanation: Atomic radius increases down Group 1: Li < Na < K.

toLevel2.question: Which element has the smallest atomic radius: sodium, magnesium, or aluminium?

options.text: Aluminium
Sodium
options.explanation: Sodium is furthest left in Period 3 and has the largest radius of these three.

options.text: Magnesium
options.explanation: Magnesium is between sodium and aluminium; aluminium has the most protons pulling electrons in.

options.text: They all have the same radius
options.explanation: Atomic radius decreases across Period 3: Na > Mg > Al.

toLevel2.question: Why does atomic radius increase going down a group?

options.text: Because each element has an additional electron shell
Because atoms lose electrons going down a group
options.explanation: Atoms do not lose electrons going down a group; they gain additional shells of electrons.

options.text: Because atoms get lighter going down a group
options.explanation: Atoms get heavier going down a group; the radius increases because of additional electron shells.

options.text: Because nuclear charge decreases going down a group
options.explanation: Nuclear charge increases going down a group, but the effect of added shells dominates.

toLevel2.template: Atomic radius {{blank:1}} across a period and {{blank:2}} down a group.
Going down a group, atoms get {{blank:1}} because they have more electron {{blank:2}}.
The atomic radius of potassium is {{blank:1}} than the atomic radius of lithium because potassium has more {{blank:2}}.

toLevel2.statement: Atomic radius increases from left to right across a period.
toLevel2.explanation: Atomic radius decreases from left to right across a period due to increasing nuclear charge.

toLevel2.statement: Fluorine has a smaller atomic radius than lithium, even though they are in the same period.
toLevel2.explanation: Fluorine is further right in Period 2 and has more protons pulling electrons closer, so its radius is smaller.

toLevel3.question: Why does atomic radius decrease across a period?

options.text: Because the number of protons increases, pulling the electrons closer to the nucleus, while the number of shells stays the same
Because electrons are removed as you go across a period
options.explanation: Electrons are added, not removed, across a period; the radius decreases because of stronger nuclear attraction.

options.text: Because the number of electron shells decreases across a period
options.explanation: The number of shells stays the same across a period; it is the increasing nuclear charge that reduces radius.

options.text: Because atoms get heavier and gravity pulls them smaller
options.explanation: Gravity is negligible at the atomic scale; the decrease is due to increasing nuclear charge.

toLevel3.question: Explain why sodium (Na) has a larger atomic radius than chlorine (Cl), even though both are in Period 3.

options.text: Chlorine has more protons (17) than sodium (11), so its nucleus pulls the electron shells closer despite both having 3 shells
Sodium has more electron shells than chlorine
options.explanation: Both have 3 electron shells; the difference is in nuclear charge.

options.text: Chlorine is a gas and gases have smaller atoms than solids
options.explanation: Physical state does not determine atomic radius; nuclear charge does.

options.text: Sodium has fewer electrons so its atom is more spread out
options.explanation: Fewer electrons and fewer protons means less nuclear pull; but the key is that chlorine's greater nuclear charge contracts its shells.

toLevel3.question: Lithium has 2 electron shells and sodium has 3 electron shells. Which has the larger atomic radius and why?

options.text: Sodium, because it has an additional electron shell making the atom larger
Lithium, because it has fewer protons pulling its electrons in
options.explanation: Although lithium has fewer protons, sodium's additional third shell makes it significantly larger.

options.text: They are the same size because both have 1 valence electron
options.explanation: Having the same number of valence electrons does not mean the same size; the number of shells differs.

options.text: Lithium, because smaller atoms have bigger radii
options.explanation: This is self-contradictory; sodium is larger because of its extra electron shell.

toLevel3.question: Which of the following correctly ranks the atoms from smallest to largest atomic radius?

options.text: F < O < N < C < B (smallest to largest across Period 2 from right to left)
B < C < N < O < F (smallest to largest across Period 2 from left to right)
options.explanation: Radius decreases left to right, so B is largest and F is smallest, not the reverse.

options.text: N < C < B < O < F (random order)
options.explanation: The correct trend is a decrease from left to right: B > C > N > O > F.

options.text: All atoms in Period 2 have the same radius
options.explanation: Atomic radius decreases across a period due to increasing nuclear charge.

toLevel3.question: A student says: 'Potassium has a larger atomic radius than calcium because it has fewer protons.' Is this the best explanation?

options.text: Yes; both are in Period 4 with the same number of shells, so potassium's lower nuclear charge means electrons are held less tightly, giving a larger radius
No; potassium is larger because it has more electron shells
options.explanation: Both potassium and calcium are in Period 4 with 4 shells; the difference is nuclear charge.

options.text: No; calcium is actually larger because it has more electrons
options.explanation: More electrons with even more protons means stronger attraction and smaller radius.

options.text: Yes; but only because potassium is a softer metal
options.explanation: Softness is a separate physical property; the radius trend is about nuclear charge and electron shells.

toLevel3.question: Which pair correctly shows the trend in atomic radius?

options.text: Li < Na < K (increasing down Group 1) and Na > Mg > Al (decreasing across Period 3)
Li > Na > K (decreasing down Group 1) and Na < Mg < Al (increasing across Period 3)
options.explanation: Both trends are reversed; radius increases down a group and decreases across a period.

options.text: Li < Na < K (increasing down Group 1) and Na < Mg < Al (increasing across Period 3)
options.explanation: The group trend is correct but the period trend is wrong; radius decreases across a period.

options.text: Li > Na > K (decreasing down Group 1) and Na > Mg > Al (decreasing across Period 3)
options.explanation: The period trend is correct but the group trend is wrong; radius increases down a group.

toLevel3.template: Across a period, the number of {{blank:1}} increases while the number of shells stays the same, causing the radius to {{blank:2}}.
Down a group, atoms have more electron {{blank:1}}, which means valence electrons are further from the {{blank:2}}, increasing atomic radius.
Sodium has a {{blank:1}} atomic radius than chlorine because chlorine has a greater {{blank:2}} charge pulling electrons closer.

toLevel3.statement: Caesium (bottom of Group 1) has the largest atomic radius of all alkali metals because it has the most electron shells.
toLevel3.explanation: Caesium has 6 electron shells, the most of any stable Group 1 element, giving it the largest atomic radius.

toLevel4.question: Sodium (Na, Period 3) has an atomic radius of 186 pm, and chlorine (Cl, Period 3) has an atomic radius of 99 pm. Calculate the approximate percentage decrease in radius from Na to Cl.

options.text: Approximately 47%, showing a significant decrease across the period
Approximately 87 pm, but we cannot express this as a percentage
options.explanation: The difference is 87 pm and this can be expressed as a percentage: (87/186) × 100 ≈ 47%.

options.text: Approximately 12%, showing a small decrease
options.explanation: The decrease is (186-99)/186 × 100 ≈ 47%, which is a substantial decrease.

options.text: Approximately 88%, meaning chlorine is almost gone
options.explanation: The calculation is (186-99)/186 × 100 ≈ 47%, not 88%.

toLevel4.question: Arrange the following elements in order of increasing atomic radius: S, Na, Mg, Cl, Al, Si, P.

options.text: Cl < S < P < Si < Al < Mg < Na
Na < Mg < Al < Si < P < S < Cl
options.explanation: This is the reverse order; atomic radius decreases from left to right across Period 3.

options.text: S < Cl < P < Si < Al < Mg < Na
options.explanation: Chlorine has a smaller radius than sulfur because it is further right in the period.

options.text: Na < Cl < Mg < S < Al < P < Si
options.explanation: This does not follow the trend; radius decreases from Na to Cl across Period 3.

toLevel4.question: Predict which has the larger atomic radius: potassium (K, Group 1, Period 4) or bromine (Br, Group 17, Period 4). Explain your reasoning.

options.text: Potassium, because it is on the far left of Period 4 with fewer protons pulling electrons in
Bromine, because it has more electrons and therefore takes up more space
options.explanation: More electrons with proportionally more protons means stronger nuclear attraction and smaller radius.

options.text: They are the same size because both are in Period 4
options.explanation: Being in the same period does not mean the same size; radius decreases across the period.

options.text: Bromine, because non-metals are always larger than metals
options.explanation: This is the opposite of the trend; metals on the left of a period are generally larger.

toLevel4.question: A student is asked whether lithium or fluorine has a larger atomic radius. They say fluorine because it has more electrons. Identify the error.

options.text: The error is that more electrons come with more protons, which pull all electrons closer; lithium has fewer protons so its electrons are held less tightly and its radius is larger
There is no error; fluorine is larger
options.explanation: Lithium has a larger radius than fluorine; radius decreases across Period 2.

options.text: The error is that fluorine has fewer electrons than lithium
options.explanation: Fluorine does have more electrons (9 vs 3); the error is in reasoning that more electrons means larger radius.

options.text: The error is that atomic radius is not related to electrons at all
options.explanation: Atomic radius is related to electrons and protons; the student's error is ignoring the effect of increased nuclear charge.

toLevel4.question: The shielding effect describes how inner electrons reduce the pull of the nucleus on outer electrons. How does this explain the increase in atomic radius down a group?

options.text: More inner electron shells provide greater shielding, reducing the effective nuclear charge felt by valence electrons, so they are held less tightly and sit further from the nucleus
Shielding removes electrons from the outer shell, making it smaller
options.explanation: Shielding does not remove electrons; it reduces the nuclear pull on outer electrons.

options.text: Shielding increases the nuclear charge, pushing outer electrons further away
options.explanation: Shielding decreases the effective nuclear charge felt by outer electrons, not increases it.

options.text: Shielding only matters across a period, not down a group
options.explanation: Shielding increases significantly down a group as more inner shells are added.

toLevel4.question: Consider lithium (2, 1) and beryllium (2, 2). Both have 2 electron shells, yet beryllium is smaller. Use nuclear charge to explain.

options.text: Beryllium has 4 protons versus lithium's 3, so the greater nuclear charge pulls the same number of shells closer to the nucleus
Beryllium is smaller because it has fewer electron shells
options.explanation: Both have 2 shells; the size difference comes from different nuclear charges.

options.text: Beryllium is smaller because it has more neutrons
options.explanation: Neutrons do not affect atomic radius; it is the proton count (nuclear charge) that matters.

options.text: Beryllium is smaller because it loses an electron to become smaller
options.explanation: We are comparing neutral atoms; beryllium's extra proton pulls its shells closer.

toLevel4.question: Francium (Fr) is at the bottom of Group 1 and on the far left of Period 7. Predict its atomic radius compared to other elements.

options.text: Francium has one of the largest atomic radii of all elements because it is at the bottom of a group and far left of a period
Francium has a small atomic radius because it has many protons
options.explanation: Although francium has many protons, it also has 7 electron shells and significant shielding, making it very large.

options.text: Francium has an average atomic radius
options.explanation: Being at the extreme bottom-left of the table gives francium an exceptionally large radius.

options.text: Atomic radius cannot be predicted for elements in Period 7
options.explanation: The same trends apply; bottom-left elements have the largest atomic radii.

toLevel4.template: The {{blank:1}} effect describes how inner electrons reduce the effective {{blank:2}} charge on outer electrons, contributing to larger radii down a group.
Across Period 3, the nuclear charge increases from {{blank:1}} protons (Na) to 17 protons (Cl), causing the atomic radius to {{blank:2}}.
Francium is predicted to have the {{blank:1}} atomic radius because it is at the {{blank:2}} of Group 1.

toLevel5.question: A student says: 'Atomic radius decreases across a period because electrons repel each other and get squeezed smaller.' Evaluate this explanation.

options.text: Incorrect; the radius decreases because of increasing nuclear charge pulling electrons closer, not electron-electron repulsion squeezing them
Correct; electron repulsion is the main cause of decreasing radius
options.explanation: Electron repulsion would actually tend to increase radius; it is the increasing nuclear charge that dominates.

options.text: Partially correct; electron repulsion and nuclear charge both decrease the radius equally
options.explanation: Electron repulsion opposes the decrease; the nuclear charge increase is the dominant factor.

options.text: Incorrect; atomic radius actually increases across a period
options.explanation: Atomic radius does decrease across a period; the student's reasoning is wrong, not the trend itself.

toLevel5.question: Compare the atomic radius of nitrogen (N) and phosphorus (P). Both are in Group 15. Which is larger and why does the increased nuclear charge of phosphorus not make it smaller?

options.text: Phosphorus is larger; although it has more protons, it has an additional electron shell that more than compensates for the increased nuclear charge
Nitrogen is larger because phosphorus has more protons pulling electrons in
options.explanation: The additional shell in phosphorus is the dominant factor, making it larger despite more protons.

options.text: They are the same size because they have the same number of valence electrons
options.explanation: Same valence electrons does not mean same size; phosphorus has an extra shell.

options.text: Phosphorus is larger only because it has more neutrons
options.explanation: Neutrons do not affect atomic radius; the additional electron shell is the key factor.

toLevel5.question: The atomic radii of Period 2 elements are: Li (152 pm), Be (112 pm), B (87 pm), C (77 pm), N (75 pm), O (73 pm), F (72 pm). The decrease from N to F is only 3 pm, while Li to Be is 40 pm. Why does the trend flatten?

options.text: Because electron-electron repulsion in the increasingly crowded outer shell partially counteracts the increasing nuclear charge, reducing the rate of decrease
Because the nuclear charge stops increasing after nitrogen
options.explanation: Nuclear charge continues to increase; the flattening is due to electron-electron repulsion.

options.text: Because fluorine starts gaining electron shells
options.explanation: All Period 2 elements have 2 shells; no additional shells are gained.

options.text: Because the measurements are inaccurate for smaller atoms
options.explanation: The measurements are accurate; the flattening is a real physical effect of electron repulsion.

toLevel5.question: When sodium forms Na⁺, its radius drops dramatically from 186 pm to 95 pm. Explain why losing one electron causes such a large change.

options.text: Removing the single valence electron eliminates the entire third shell, and the remaining 10 electrons are pulled closer by the 11 protons
The atom loses a proton when it forms an ion, making the nucleus smaller
options.explanation: Ion formation involves electron loss, not proton loss; the nucleus stays the same.

options.text: The electron that is lost was very large and took up a lot of space
options.explanation: Individual electrons do not have size in this sense; removing it eliminates a whole shell level.

options.text: The radius decrease is small and not significant
options.explanation: A drop from 186 pm to 95 pm is nearly 50% and is very significant.

toLevel5.question: Predict which is larger: a potassium atom (K) or a calcium ion (Ca²⁺). Both have 18 electrons in the arrangement 2, 8, 8. Explain your reasoning.

options.text: Potassium (K) is larger in its atomic form (2, 8, 8, 1), but as K⁺ (2, 8, 8) it is larger than Ca²⁺ (2, 8, 8) because Ca²⁺ has 20 protons pulling 18 electrons versus K⁺'s 19 protons
They are the same size because they have the same number of electrons
options.explanation: Same electron configuration but different nuclear charges means different sizes; more protons = smaller.

options.text: Ca²⁺ is larger because calcium is further right on the periodic table
options.explanation: As an ion, Ca²⁺ has more protons pulling the same number of electrons, making it smaller, not larger.

options.text: K is smaller because it is a lighter element
options.explanation: Mass does not determine radius; the comparison depends on nuclear charge versus electron configuration.

toLevel5.question: A student claims that helium should have the smallest atomic radius of all elements because it is at the top-right of the periodic table. Evaluate this claim.

options.text: The claim is reasonable based on trends; helium has the fewest shells and is on the right, though it is placed in Group 18 for chemical reasons rather than radius trends
The claim is wrong because hydrogen is smaller than helium
options.explanation: Helium actually has a smaller measured atomic radius than hydrogen because its 2 protons hold 2 electrons more tightly.

options.text: The claim is wrong because noble gases have the largest radii in each period
options.explanation: Noble gases generally have small atomic radii (when using covalent/empirical measures) due to high nuclear charge.

options.text: The claim is wrong because atomic radius is not related to position on the table
options.explanation: Position on the table strongly correlates with atomic radius through the established trends.

toLevel5.question: Why do the two trends in atomic radius (decrease across period, increase down group) arise from different underlying causes?

options.text: Across a period, the shell number stays constant and increasing protons dominate; down a group, additional shells dominate over the increased nuclear charge due to shielding
Both trends are caused by the same factor: increasing nuclear charge
options.explanation: Increasing nuclear charge explains the decrease across a period but not the increase down a group.

options.text: Both trends are caused by the same factor: adding electron shells
options.explanation: Shells are only added down a group; across a period, the number of shells is constant.

options.text: The trends are random and cannot be explained by simple factors
options.explanation: Both trends have clear explanations based on nuclear charge and electron shell number.

toLevel5.question: Gallium (Ga, Period 4) has an atomic radius of 136 pm, which is only slightly larger than aluminium (Al, Period 3) at 143 pm. Why is the increase smaller than expected going down Group 13?

options.text: Because gallium has d-electrons (from the transition metals before it in Period 4) that provide poor shielding, so the effective nuclear charge is higher than expected
Because gallium has fewer electron shells than aluminium
options.explanation: Gallium has 4 shells versus aluminium's 3; the poor shielding from d-electrons explains the anomaly.

options.text: Because the periodic table trend breaks down in Period 4
options.explanation: The trend still applies; the d-block contraction is a known modification to the basic trend.

options.text: Because aluminium and gallium are different elements and cannot be compared
options.explanation: Elements in the same group are routinely compared; the d-block contraction explains the anomaly.
